entry.title: New Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 1
entry.content:
Where do I start?

If you are unfamiliar with the new Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities (PCC-MPA), I recommend visiting this blog where its features are explained.

 

Audience

As this is an implementation guide that will lead you to a series of technical and functional steps, the objective audience is payroll implementation experts: consultants, solution architects and project managers.

They will need to know how the destination payroll works to better align the PCC-MPA solution with their needs. Aspects such as understanding the steps of the payroll process, their order of precedence, and their expected execution date ranges are a must.

 

What's this guide for?

First, let's set expectations by detailing what this guide is not:

  • It is not a replacement for the official guide. 
  • It is not a replacement for the Best Practice documentation (Note: 3570410).
  • It is not a thorough guide where all the configuration steps are explained in detail.
  • It is not the official localization for the Spanish payroll.

So, what is it then? Or, even better, what is it good for?

  • This series of blogs will guide you through the configuration of the product so you can have a minimum viable product (MVP) up and running, starting from the scratch.
  • This MVP is a prototype of an end-to-end Spanish payroll process, where some pre-payroll and post-payroll processes are included to highlight the PCC-MPA features, while showing an example of localization/customization based on the standard content.
  • The reason the Spanish payroll is the one selected is because it is the one I know best, but consultants experienced in other localizations will easily understand how to adapt it to their own localizations and specific custom needs. 
  • This series of blogs summarizes the official documentation so you can reach this MVP without losing yourself into the multiple possibilities that the solution offers.
  • The final MVP may not be the best and, certainly, won't be your final version, but you will have a straightforward and tested way to get it working, enabling you to understand better the solution and its possibilities.
  • It will also contain a final chapter with operational and administration tips.

 

Technical Prerequisites

As detailed in the official guide:

The second point is only necessary if you are implementing it in an Employee Central Payroll system.

 

Business Requirements

To configure the PCC-MPA, the following requirements for the destination payroll must be met:

  • The overall payroll process must already be implemented or in the final steps of the implementation, as the PCC-MPA will be the application on top managing the whole system.
  • Pre- and post-payroll activities, whether standard or custom, must be identified and already configured.
  • A diagram of the steps of the payroll process, their order of precedence, and their expected execution date ranges are also useful to create the activity list object as automated as possible.
  • A list of the validation rules and analytical graphics that will be used in the monitoring. RDS models can be used in an initial version to be further extended in posterior iterations.

 

General Assumptions

  • SAP Best Practices have been installed following the official documentation (Note: 3570410).
  • As mentioned before, this guide shows the way to implement a localization for the Spanish payroll. Most objects are not country-specific, but,  whenever Spanish-specific objects are used, they will be indicated. 
  • Each part/blog will show relevant examples of the configuration section it focuses on, and will include with the full list of the objects created for this MVP.
  • When a SAP Best Practice object is used as a model (most of the time), its ID is marked with the label [SBP] for convenience.
  • As is usually with SAP configuration: copy when possible, and then adapt/change when needed.
  • This guide is intended to be used alongside the official one, as it will follow the steps of Implementation Overview of Payroll Control Center: Manage Payroll Activities, and most questions that may arise about specific topics will be answered there.
  • Role granularity is not addressed, as a single user is the one used both for administratotion and configuration.
  • All the quotes to the official guide appear in italics.

 

Next Chapter

In the next chapter we will continue with the initial technical set-up:

PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 2 - Technical Set-up

entry.title: New Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 4
entry.content:
Previous Chapters

To understand the new Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities (PCC-MPA), I recommend visiting this blog where its features are explained.

Previous chapters:

  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 1 - Basis
  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 2 - Technical Set-up 
  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 3 - Configuration Workbench 

 

Summary

In this blog we address all the actions done in the frontend application Set-up Payroll Activities.

This tool is the web-based application where the most important objects are created and defined. Once the system is configured an running, it will be the only place where the administrators adapt and extend the solution.

This chapter includes the topics from the corresponding sections of the official guide:

  • Analytics Designers
  • Configuring Validation Rules
  • Configuring Policies
  • Configuring Steps
  • Configuring Activities
  • Configuring Activity Lists

 

Key concepts

Here is the detailed terminology as described in this chapter of the guide. Underlined are the ones addressed in this chapter:

  • action: A dynamic URL that can generate the value at run time and points to a link where payroll administrators or payroll manager can update employees' master data or check further details.
  • activity: The sequence of all steps that are required to execute payroll and all related activities (for example, legal reporting) for a specific entity.
  • activity list: The combination of one or more relevant payroll activities in a complete payroll cycle.
  • activity list type: Collects the relevant technical details (such as country/region and the activity list logic) for subsequent configuration of activity lists.
  • activity type: Collects the relevant technical details (such as country/region and the activity logic) for subsequent configuration of activities.
  • alert entity: A result parameter type for which alerts are given based on check results from validation rules.
  • analytics designer: Program output, table layout, simple form of label-value pairs, or different types of charts to provide details for a validation rule or step execution.
  • analytics designer type: Collects the relevant technical details (such as country/region and the design logic) for subsequent configuration of analytics designers.
  • policy: A set of validation rules grouped according to your needs. A policy helps you to achieve payroll compliance.
  • recurrence of payroll activity list: Defines an activity list in payroll for a specific organization level and period.
  • step: A single step within a payroll activity.
  • step type: Collects the relevant technical details (such as country/region and the step logic) for subsequent configuration of steps.
  • validation rule: A check function executed by the system to identify compliance violations or potential risks.
  • validation rule type: Collects the relevant technical context (such as country/region and the run time class with all supported variables) for defining a validation rule.

 

Set Up Payroll Activities

https://[BASE_URL]/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/hrpy_pcc_ctl_v2/index.html

 

Analytics Designer

Imagine these objects as windows into the payroll, as they visually summarize step outputs provide an interactive overview of the payroll status.

Bear in mind that they are used in two situations:

  • Step Output: Often the spool output is enough to know what has happened, but for other steps, such as Monitoring, analytics become the real thermometer of the payroll health.
  • Alert details: Also called Root Cause Analysis, they display graphically the details of the payroll of the employees that causes each alert. They are very useful to understand and solve them directly, with direct access links to related transactions.

A key feature of these objects is drill-down navigation: clicking tiles opens more detailed views.

In this example, I copied some of the original SBP objects and set the country to the final payroll (04-Spain, in this example). As you will see, there are plenty of them in the SBP and they are very powerful. In the real world these objects will be among the most customized ones. Happily, taking the SBP objects as a reference, makes adaptation easy.

To organize them, I have added the prefix "RCA" to the analytics designers that are intended for validation rules.

Here the list:

FinalOrigin
(ZES_ALERTS_COUNT) Count of Alerts[SBP] SBP - XX - Alerts Overview
(ZES_ALERTS_LIST) Alerts List[SBP] SBP - XX - List of Alerts
(ZES_ALERTS_LIST_VR) Alerts List by Validation Rule[SBP] SBP -XX - Alerts Overview (List By Validation Rule)
(ZES_ALERTS_OVERVIEW) Alerts Overview (Chart)[SBP] SBP - XX - Alerts Overview (Pie Chart)
(ZES_ALERTS_POLICY) Alerts by Policy[SBP] SBP - XX - Alerts By Policy
(ZES_ALERTS_STATUS) Alerts by Status[SBP] SBP - XX - Alerts By Policy
(ZES_ALERTS_TEAM) Alerts by Team[SBP] SBP - XX - Alerts By Team
(ZES_ALERTS_VR) Alerts by Validation Rule[SBP] SBP - XX - Alerts By Validation Rule
(ZES_EMPL_SCOPE) Employees in Scope[SBP] SBP - XX - Employees in Scope
(ZES_GROSS_HISTORY) Gross History (Global)[SBP] SBP - US - Total Gross History over the last 6 payroll periods
(ZES_GROSS_NET_COMPAR) Gross and Net Comparison[SBP] SBP - XX - Payroll gross and net comparison for last 6 payroll periods
(ZES_JOB_INFO) Job Information[SBP] SBP - XX - Job Output
(ZES_PAYMENT_HISTORY) Payment History[SBP] SBP - US - Payment History
(ZES_PAYMENT_OVERVIEW) Payment Overview (Global)[SBP] SBP - US - Payment Overview USA
(ZES_PAYROLL_MESSAGES_LIST) Payroll Messages List[SBP] SBP - XX - Employee Payroll Messages Details
(ZES_PAYROLL_MESSAGES_TYPE) Payroll Messages by Type[SBP] SBP - XX - Employee Payroll Messages By Message Type
(ZES_PAYSLIP_PERDATE) Payslip per Period[SBP] SBP - RCA - Payslip based on current period Test Payroll results
(ZES_POLICY_JOB_RESULTS) Policy Job Results[SBP] SBP - XX - Job output
(ZES_RCA_ALERT_DETAILS) Alert Details[SBP] SBP -XX - Alert Details - Navigation
(ZES_RCA_GROSS_HISTORY) Gross History[SBP] SBP - US - Total Gross History over the last 6 payroll periods
(ZES_RCA_PAYMENT_HISTORY) Payment History[SBP] SBP - US - Payment History
(ZES_RCA_PAYMENT_OVERVIEW) Payment Overview[SBP] SBP - US - Payment Overview USA
(ZES_RCA_PAYSLIP_CURRENT) Payslip Current Period[SBP] SBP - RCA - Productive Payslip Current Period
(ZES_RCA_PAYSLIP_PREVIOUS) Payslip Previous Period[SBP] SBP - RCA - Productive Payslip Previous Period
(ZES_RCA_SOLUTIONS) Alert Solutions[SBP] SBP - XX - Solutions
(ZES_RCA_WAGETYPE_LIST) Wagetype List (employee)[SBP] SBP - XX - Simple payroll result list
(ZES_RCA_WAGETYPE_LIST_COMP) Wagetype List Comparison (employee)[SBP] SBP - RCA - Wagetype comparison current period vs previous period
(ZES_RETRO_HISTORY) Retro History[SBP] SBP - XX - Count of Employees with Retro payroll runs
(ZES_SPOOL_OUTPUT) Spool Output[SBP] SBP - XX - Job output

 

Validation Rules

These objects are essential for the monitoring step. They determine when payroll calculations should be analyzed further by the payroll experts because they meet a predefined condition. 

You can also assign Analytics Designer objects to each rule as Root Cause Analysis. In this example, for simplicity, I assigned all RCA-prefixed analytics to every rule.

SBP provides useful alerts grouped as:

  • Wagetype amounts above threshold
  • Cross-wagetype amounts comparison
  • Cross-periods amounts comparison
  • Missing infotypes data
  • Payroll Messages

With this possibilities you should be able to handle most of the situations of any payroll implementation.

But, what if you want to check a very specific and complex validation that cannot be addressed by these formulations? Don't panic, there is a workaround that will allow customers to set the most challenging condition. The key is the payroll engine. Yes, as simple as that. Here the recipe:

  1. Create a custom alert wagetype that only need to be stored in the RT.
  2. Create a payroll rule (or set of rules, or even custom function, your choice) that sets the wagetype to a non-zero value when the complex condition is met.
  3. Place this rule appropriately in the payroll schema (final part).
  4. Create a simple validation rule that checks for this wagetype â‰  0.

That's all. Not that complicated right? As the payroll engine is very powerful in all type of calculations there won't be a problem to generate an alert wagetype.

Here a list of the limited alerts used in this example:

FinalOrigin / Reference
(ZES_CLAIMS) Employees with Claims[SBP] SBP - XX - C032 - Employees with claims
(ZES_EMPLOYEE_REJECTED) Employee Rejected[SBP] SBP - XX - C047 - Employees rejected in the payroll execution
(ZES_GROSS_ABOVE_TH) Gross Above Threshold[SBP] SBP - US - C026 - Employees with Gross pay over threshold amount ( 10,000 $ )
(ZES_IRPF_PERC_INCR) IRPF Percentage IncreaseIt is not a clone but it is very similar to  SBP - XX - C043 - Employees with variance in net pay over threshold percentage ( 5 % ), with a different wagetype and threshold.
(ZES_MISSING_IT0009) Missing Bank Account Information[SBP] SBP - XX - C009 - Employees missing main bank details
(ZES_MISSING_IT0062) Missing Tax InformationSimilar to the previous one getting information from a Spanish payroll standard infotype that had been added in the general Validation Rule Type (see previous chapter)
(ZES_NET_ABOVE_TH) Net Pay Above Threshold[SBP] SBP - XX - C030 - Employees with net pay greater than threshold value ( 5000 $ )
(ZES_OVERTIME_OVER_PAY) Overtime exceeding 25% of total pay[SBP] SBP - US - C035 - Employees with overtime exceeding (25%) percent of total pay
(ZES_PERC_ABOVE_100) Employment Percentage Above 100Similar to SBP - XX - C001 - Employment percentage does not match utilization (IT0007/IT0008)
(ZES_RETROACTIVITY) Employee with Retro Amount in NetSimilar to SBP - XX - C044 - Employees with large retroactive calculations

 

Policies

Just one Policy with all the previous rules:

 

Steps

These objects are steps. No brainer. Many SBP steps can be reused with minimal changes, primarily checking input parameters. You can define dependencies, parameters, and job execution behavior.

A standout feature is that using the step types of "Generic Job Step" or "PNP Report Job Step" (see previous chapter), any report existing in your payroll system can be executed, allowing customers full control of standard and custom processes.

Important note: parameters can be tricky, specially in background execution. Some hints will be provided in the final chapter.


Here the list of the steps used in this example. In this case, there are some steps that are running standard Spanish Payroll reports that I will detail below. They may be useful also for non-Spanish adaptation as they show how complex reports parameters can be passed:

FinalOrigin / Reference
(ZES_CALENDAR) Spain Calendar GenerationDetailed below
(ZES_CLOSE_PAYROLL) Close Payroll[SBP] SBP - XX - Close Payroll
(ZES_CREATE_POSTING) Create Payroll Posting Document[SBP] SBP - XX - Create Payroll Posting Document
(ZES_MONITORING) Monitoring[SBP] SBP - XX - Monitoring Master Data
(ZES_OPEN_PAYROLL) Open Payroll[SBP] SBP - XX - Start Payroll
(ZES_PAYROLL_PRD) Productive Payroll[SBP] SBP - US - Execute Productive Payroll
(ZES_PAYROLL_PRD_PPEE) Productive Payroll Extra Payments[SBP] SBP - US - Execute Productive Payroll (different schema)
(ZES_PAYROLL_SIM) Spanish Payroll Simulation[SBP] SBP - US - Create Test Payroll Results
(ZES_POLICIES) Init Policies Job[SBP] SBP - XX - Execute Policies, Generate Alerts and Sync Teams
(ZES_PREPARE_DME) Transfers Prepare DME[SBP] SBP - US - Create DME File
(ZES_RELEASE_POSTING) Release Posting Document[SBP] SBP - XX - Release Payroll Posting Document
(ZES_SIGNOFF) Sign-Off Dashboard[SBP] SBP - US - Sign-Off Dashboard
(ZES_SIMULATE_POSTING) Simulate Posting[SBP] SBP - XX - Simulate Posting with Test Payroll Result
(ZES_SLD_BASES) Spain Social Security (SLD Bases)Detailed below
(ZES_TAXES_111) Spain Taxes (111 Model)Detailed below
(ZES_TAX_BATCH_INPUTS) Spain Tax Batch InputsDetailed below
(ZES_TAX_REPORT) Spain Tax ReportDetailed below
(ZES_TRANSFER_FILE) Create Transfer File[SBP] SBP - US - Create DME File
(ZES_TRANSFER_POSTING) Transfer Payroll Posting Document[SBP] SBP - XX - Transfer Payroll Posting Document to SAP Finance
 

NOTE: In these examples all steps have been categorized as generic, even those PNP, for an extra control in dates. It is important because the way of passing parameters differs.

 

(ZES_CALENDAR) Spain Calendar Generation

Mandatory report previous to payroll calculation to generate calendar data.

 

NOTE: Here you can see how to pass dates to a PNP report.

 

(ZES_SLD_BASES) Spain Social Security (SLD Bases)

Report to generate Social Security files as TemSe. 

NOTE: To obtain the file from this step, another analytics designer with the link to the TemSe transaction may be interesting. Missing in this example.

 

NOTE: an example to pass the Current Period selection parameter.

(ZES_TAX_REPORT) Spain Tax Report

Report to generate the Batch Inputs to update a standard infotype for taxes in Spain.

(ZES_TAX_BATCH_INPUTS) Spain Tax Batch Inputs

Report that gets the previously generated Batch Input and runs it.

 

 

(ZES_TAXES_111) Spain Taxes (111 Model)

Report to generate the information to fulfill Taxes 111 Model

 

 

Activities

Groups of steps executed in sequence with optional automatic start and confirmation. 

Here the list:

FinalOrigin / Reference
(ZES_ACT_RPIGA0E0) Spain TaxesDetailed below
(ZES_CALENDAR) Spain Calendar GenerationDetailed below
(ZES_CLOSE_PAYROLL) Close Payroll[SBP] SBP - US - Provide Payroll Sign Off
(ZES_GENERATE_PAYMENTS) Generate Employee Payment File[SBP] SBP - US - Create Employee Payment File
(ZES_MONITORING_ES01) Monitoring ES01[SBP] SBP - US - Monitoring Payroll Data Quality
(ZES_MONITORING_ES02) Monitoring ES02[SBP] SBP - US - Monitoring Payroll Data Quality
(ZES_MONITORING_TEST) (TEST) Monitoring[SBP] SBP - US - Monitoring Payroll Data Quality
(ZES_PAYROLL_DATA_SIM) Create Test Payroll Results[SBP] SBP - US - Create Test Payroll Results
(ZES_PAYROLL_POSTING) Payroll Posting[SBP] SBP - US - Productive Payroll Posting
(ZES_POSTING_SIM) Payroll Posting Simulated[SBP] SBP - XX - Simulate Posting with Test Payroll Results
(ZES_PRODUCTIVE_PAYROLL) Productive Payroll[SBP] SBP - US - Productive Payroll
(ZES_PRODUCTIVE_PAYROLL_PPEE) Productive Payroll Extra Payments[SBP] SBP - US - Productive Payroll (different schema)
(ZES_SOCSEC_SLD) Spain Social Security (SLD)Detailed below
(ZES_TAXES) Spain TaxesDetailed below

 

Some examples:

(ZES_ACT_RPIGA0E0) Spain Taxes

(ZES_CALENDAR) Spain Calendar Generation

(ZES_SOCSEC_SLD) Spain Social Security (SLD)

(ZES_TAXES) Spain Taxes

Activity Lists

The final layer that defines the end-to-end process by linking activities together, setting dates and filtering employee groups.

I created three examples:

  • Simple monitoring: It just calculates, evaluates and monitor the payroll.
  • General payroll: the end-to-end Spanish payroll example
  • Special Payments Payroll: Spanish Specific special payments process

 

(ZES_ACL_MONITORING) Activities List Base

The simplest process of all. Just monitoring. In any case, very powerful to display the payroll status at any moment.

(ZES_GENERAL_PAYROLL) General Payroll

 The final example with all the activities.

 

 
(ZES_GENERAL_PAYROLL_PPEE) General Payroll (With Special Payments)

A variant for the Special Payments. Just differences shown.

Next Chapter

Once all the configuration is ready, the next chapter explains how to operate the system and includes some technical administration tips.

PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 5 - Operation & Administration

entry.title: New Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 3
entry.content:
Previous Chapters

To understand the new Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities (PCC-MPA), I recommend visiting this blog where its features are explained.

Previous chapters:

  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 1 - Basis
  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 2 - Technical Set-up 

 

Summary

In this blog we  address all actions done in the Configuration Workbench (Manage Payroll Activities) transaction.

The Configuration Workbench is the backend configuration tool where the basic object types are defined. These basic types are later used in the frontend application to define the data and behavior of the final objects of the solution.

This chapter covers the following sections of the official guide:

  • Configuring Analytics Designer Types
  • Actions for Solution Links and Step Links in Activity Lists
  • Configuring Validation Rule Types
  • Configuring Step Types
  • Configuring Activity Types
  • Configuring Activity List Types

 

Key concepts

Here is a detailed list of  terminology as explained in this chapter of the guide. Underlined the ones addressed in this chapter:

  • action: A dynamic URL that can generate the value at run time and points to a link where payroll administrators or payroll manager can update employees' master data or check further details.
  • activity: The sequence of all steps that are required to execute payroll and all related activities (for example, legal reporting) for a specific entity.
  • activity list: The combination of one or more relevant payroll activities in a complete payroll cycle.
  • activity list type: Collects the relevant technical details (such as country/region and the activity list logic) for subsequent configuration of activity lists.
  • activity type: Collects the relevant technical details (such as country/region and the activity logic) for subsequent configuration of activities.
  • alert entity: A result parameter type for which alerts are given based on check results from validation rules.
  • analytics designer: Program output, table layout, simple form of label-value pairs, or different types of charts to provide details for a validation rule or step execution.
  • analytics designer type: Collects the relevant technical details (such as country/region and the design logic) for subsequent configuration of analytics designers.
  • policy: A set of validation rules grouped according to your needs. A policy helps you to achieve payroll compliance.
  • recurrence of payroll activity list: Defines an activity list in payroll for a specific organization level and period.
  • step: A single step within a payroll activity.
  • step type: Collects the relevant technical details (such as country/region and the step logic) for subsequent configuration of steps.
  • validation rule: A check function executed by the system to identify compliance violations or potential risks.
  • validation rule type: Collects the relevant technical context (such as country/region and the run time class with all supported variables) for defining a validation rule.

 

 

Configuration Workbench

Transaction PYT_CONF_WB

IMPORTANT NOTE: Do not confuse this with the transaction PYC_CONF_WB - Configuration Workbench (Payroll Process). That transaction is used to configure the former Payroll Control Center - Process Management.

NOTES:

  • All configurations have been done with the Country: 04 â€“ Spain. Adapt accordingly for other payrolls.
  • To easily identify all the objects, the ZES prefix has been used as a naming convention.
  • The configuration contains mainly standard international payroll reports, plus some mandatory reports for the Spanish payroll, used here as an example.
  • Spanish-specific reports and derived objects are clearly labeled â€œSpainâ€ in their chapter title.
  • When an SAP Best Practice (SBP) object can be copied or used as a reference, it is indicated by the label [SBP].

 

Actions

  • Employee Profile - ZES_ACT_EC_PROFILE:

{{SYSTEM_EC}}/sf/liveprofile?blockId=[[BLOCKTYPE_EC]]&selected_user=[[EMPLOYEE_ID_EC]]

[SBP]: SBP_V2_ACL_EC_PEOPLE_PROFILE

  • ECP User Menu - ZES_ECP:

{{SYSTEM}}/SAP/BC/GUI/SAP/ITS/WEBGUI

  • Backend Transaction (skip first) - ZES_ECP_TRANSACTION:

{{SYSTEM}}/SAP/BC/GUI/SAP/ITS/WEBGUI?~TRANSACTION=*[[STRANS]]

  • Backend Transaction (NO skip first) â€“ ZES_ECP_TRANSACTION_NOSKIP

{{SYSTEM}}/SAP/BC/GUI/SAP/ITS/WEBGUI?~TRANSACTION=[[STRANS]]

  • Go to Job - ZES_GOTOJOB

{{SYSTEM}}/SAP/BC/GUI/SAP/ITS/WEBGUI?~TRANSACTION=*SM37 BTCH2170-JOBNAME=[[POLICYID]];BTCH2170-USERNAME=*;DYNP_OKCODE=DOIT;BTCH2170-FROM_DATE=[[CLASSID]];BTCH2170-TO_DATE=[[CRU_BASE_SAL_WG]];BTCH2170-FROM_TIME=[[BUKRS]];BTCH2170-TO_TIME=[[BUKRS]]

[SBP]: SBP_V2_LINK_GOTO_JOB

  • Go to PA03 - ZES_GOTOPA03

{{SYSTEM}}/SAP/BC/GUI/SAP/ITS/WEBGUI?~TRANSACTION=*PA03 PV000-ABKRS=[[ABKRS]];DYNP_OKCODE=MOD;

  • Go to Spool - ZES_GOTOSPOOL

{{SYSTEM}}/sap/bc/gui/sap/its/webgui?~transaction=*SP01%20DYNP_OKCODE=CRET;S_RQIDEN-LOW=[[SpoolId]]

  • Generic Mashup - ZES_ITXXXX_MASHUP

{{SYSTEM}}{{SBP_HR_RENEWAL}}&OBJID=[[EMPLOYEE_ID]]&CFG_ID=[[INFTY]]

[SBP]: SBP_V2_ACL_MASHUP

  • IT through PA30 - ZES_ITXXXX_PA30

{{SYSTEM}}{{SBP_WEBGUI_PA30}}%20RP50G-CHOIC=[[INFTY]];RP50G-PERNR=[[EMPLOYEE_ID]];DYNP_OKCODE=MOD

[SBP]: SBP_V2_ACL_WEBGUI_PA30

  • Payroll Simulation - ZES_PAYROLL_SIM

{{SYSTEM}}/SAP/BC/GUI/SAP/ITS/WEBGUI?~TRANSACTION=*PC00_M04_CALC_SIMU PNPXABKR=[[ABKRS]];PNPABKRS-LOW=[[ABKRS]];SCHEMA=[[SCHEMA]];PRT_PROT=X;PNPPERNR-LOW=[[PERNR]]

NOTE: Change the transaction for the local payroll simulation

  •  Access TemSe Files - ZES_TEMSE

{{SYSTEM}}/SAP/BC/GUI/SAP/ITS/WEBGUI?~TRANSACTION=PC00_M04_UTMS

NOTE: Spanish file generation transaction

  •  URL Example â€“ Wiki - ZES_URL_WIKI

NOTE: add any url that can be useful. 

  • Go to Wage Report - ZES_WAGEREPORT

{{SYSTEM}}/SAP/BC/GUI/SAP/ITS/WEBGUI?~TRANSACTION=*PC00_M99_CWTR

 

Activity List Types

  • Generic Activity List Type - ZES_ACL_TYPE:

[SBP] SBP_V2_ACTIVITY_LIST

 

Activity Types

  • Generic Activity List Type - ZES_ACL_TYPE:

[SBP] SBP_V2_ACTIVITY_TYPE

 

Activity Designer Types

 

  • Base ADT - ZHR_ES_BASE_ADT:

[SBP] SBP_V2_MASTER_DATA

NOTE: Only one object is used here for testing, containing all dimensions. For performance reasons, splitting into multiple objects is recommended. Added all infotypes that could be useful to show in analytics.

Dimensions (underlined the ones exclusive for Spain):

  • PA2001 Absences
  • PA0000 Actions
  • PA0090 Additional Income E
  • PA0015 Additional payments
  • HRPY_PCC_BPCM_GEN All Job Messages
  • PA0009 Bank Details
  • PA0008 Basic pay
  • PA0105 Communication
  • PA0016 Contract Elements
  • PA0887 Deductions (ES)
  • HRPY_PCC_ALERT_EE Employee Alerts
  • HRPY_PCC_BPCM_EE Employee Job Messages
  • PA0480 Enhancement: Contracts Processing
  • PA0011 External transfers
  • PA0062 Fiscal Data S
  • __PAY_MESSAGES_GEN Generic Payroll Messages
  • __P2RX_WPBP_INDEX HRDCD HELPER TABLES FOR WPBP
  • HRPY_PCC_BPCR_EE Job - Rejected Employees
  • HRPY_PCC_STEP_JOB Job Information
  • PA0001 Organizational assignment
  • __PAY_DIRECTORY Payroll Directory
  • __PAY_MATCH_W Payroll Matchcode W
  • __PAY_MESSAGES Payroll Messages
  • __PERIODS_DATES Payroll Periods and Dates
  • __P2RX_RT Payroll Results: Results Table
  • __P2RX_WPBP Payroll Results: Work Center/Basic Pay
  • PA0002 Personal data
  • PA0014 Recurring Payments/Deductions
  • HRPY_PCC_ACTIVITY Selection
  • PA0092 Seniority E
  • PA0061 Social Insurance S

Results:

  • PA2001 Absences
  • PA0000 Actions
  • PA0090 Additional Income E
  • PA0015 Additional payments
  • HRPY_PCC_BPCM_GEN All Job Messages
  • PA0009 Bank Details
  • PA0008 Basic pay
  • PA0105 Communication
  • PA0016 Contract Elements
  • PA0887 Deductions (ES)
  • HRPY_PCC_ALERT_EE Employee Alerts
  • EE_DEM Employee Demographics
  • HRPY_PCC_BPCM_EE Employee Job Messages
  • PA0480 Enhancement: Contracts Processing

entry.title: New Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 5
entry.content:
Previous Chapters

To understand the new Payroll Control Center - Manage Payroll Activities (PCC-MPA), I recommend visiting this blog where features are explained.

Previous chapters:

  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 1 - Basis
  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 2 - Technical Set-up 
  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 3 - Configuration Workbench 
  • PCC - Manage Payroll Activities - Simple Implementation Guide - Part 4 - Set-up Payroll Activities.

 

Summary

In this blog we summarize how to operate and administrate the system just configured. Some useful tricks for adaptation, configuration, and debugging are also included.

 

Initial Administration

I just followed the steps in the PYT_ADMIN_TRANSACTION in the backend to set the system up and ready. 

Batch Processing -> [MASTER USER]

bgRFC inbound Destination: set as follows

Recurrence for Event Handler Jobs: set recurrence and start the job 

User List for Master Data Maintenance

 

Business Processes of Managing Payroll Activities

 

Plan Payroll Activities

https://[BASE_URL]/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/hrpy_pcc_pal_v1/index.html

Enter data and click on â€œReset Recurrence Datesâ€ to generate calendar according to Activity List configuration:

Then click Activate.

Set Up Teams

https://[BASE_URL]/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/hrpy_pcc_ctm_v1/index.html

For the first recurrence of an Activity List, create a Team for each monitoring activity and assign members. Subsequent recurrences keep the same team:

For the sake of simplicity just one user added, add as many as you need:

 

Manage Payroll Activities

https://[BASE_URL]/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/hrpy_pcc_mal_v1/index.html

Click in the button Manage Activity List:

Select your Activity List and Recurrence (just created in the step before):

Click on Activate Recurrence and Start Recurrence and the status will change to â€œOn Goingâ€:

Once active you can follow the whole process from the Home in the same page:

Selecting each box, you can start activities and steps within activities

Once it is over you can click over to analyse its result:

Click on the glasses icon and navigate to see the spool:

Keep on executing activities following the Activity List:

 

Manage Ongoing Processes

Restart Step, Activity or Activity List

In Manage Payroll Activities you can restart every step or activity using the corresponding icons

To restart the whole process, the same icon is found at Activity List level:

 

Restart Recurrence

After relevant changes in the Activity Lists, Activities or Steps configuration, it may be needed to regenerate the recurrence, so the system gets updated.

Click on Manage Activity Lists:

Select the recurrence to regenerate and click "Delete":

Then you need to activate it and start it again.

 

Monitoring

The monitoring action and the precedent of â€œPolicies Executionâ€ are special as they trigger different processes:

  • Alerts calculation
  • Team assignment
  • Analytics Designer tiles generation in:
    • Each alert as a Root Clause Analysis
    • The monitoring activity itself as payroll KPIs

Here an example:

Expanding each section, you can navigate further (according to configuration in the Set Up Payroll Activities section).

As a payroll administrator (user in the Team assigned in the â€œSet Up Teamsâ€ action) you can navigate to the page â€œManage Alertsâ€ to analyze each KPI further:

Also, with the direct url:

https://[BASE_URL]/sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/hrpy_pcc_mat_v1/index.html

Clicking on the upper right icon, you can toggle between the â€œValidation Typeâ€ view:

And the â€œEmployeeâ€ view:

You can assign each alert and analyze it using the Root Alert Causes that have been configured in the Validation Rule configuration:

 

Administration

Report PYT_ADMIN_TRANSACTION

From the Administer Payroll Activities action, you can perform the same actions on each Step and Activity as in Manage Payroll Activities. 

NOTE: Sometimes frontend actions donâ€™t work. Stopping stuck steps may only work from the backend here.

You can also regenerate the recurrence with the action â€œRegenerate Activity List Recurrenceâ€.

Technical Tricks

General Usability

  • In the Set Up Payroll Activities page, it is very useful to activate the visualization of the IDs. This is done in the settings in the upper-right icon:

Also, the legend for the charts:

  • When configuring new Validation Rules and Designers, the Preview feature allows testing with a predefined dataset before assigning it to an activity:

 

Jobs & Variants

Each Step has an associated job, visible from the SM37 transaction:

As a consultant, it is interesting to see the Job log to understand which is the exact program and variant that the system is executing:

The variant is visible in the SE38 (variant subobject):

 

Miscellanea

 

  • To debug steps in execution you can set the debug point this FM: PYT_STEP_JOB_SCHEDULE. When the process is started by PYT_ADMIN_TRANSACTION report (Administer Payroll Activities) with start/ stop you donâ€™t need to put an external debugging point. It is useful, for example, to ensure that you get the right parameters passed.
  • Validation Rules and Policies:
    • Report for policies and VR PYT_EXECUTE_POLICIES_ACT.
    • Table where the alerts are stored: PYT_D_ALERT
    • Debugging of VR : CL_PYC_TSK_VR_BASE_3         IF_PYD_TY_RT~EXECUTE
  • Common Pitfall: When setting a Job in an object Step, consider the whole radiobutton group parameters, not only the one you need, because otherwise you will get an error in ST22 of too many radiobuttons. This error isnâ€™t shown anywhere else, and the step keeps working forever with the job status â€œScheduledâ€ and never started. So, unless you enter in the ST22, you won't know what happens.
  • For any Step change you need to restart the recurrence (no need to recreate it, just restart it from the beginning).
  • Relevant tables:
    • RELIDs:
      • DN: Analytics Designer
      • VR: Validation Rules
      • KP: KPI
      • AS: Activity Step Assignment
    • PYC_D_TL_REC
    • PYC_D_TL_RECT
    • PYC_D_TASK_RECUR
    • PYC_D_TASK
    • PYC_D_STEP_RECUR
    • PYT_D_ACT_RESO
    • Configuration Cluster PYC_D_CONF_CL

 

Final thoughts

Hope you have found this series of blogs useful, and may it help you in your initial activations of this powerful functionality.

entry.title: Re: Do you know if there is a corresponding long text or...
entry.content:
QAMV is the table for Inspection lot characteristics. KURZTEXT is the short text of the characteristic (essentially the description of the MIC â€“ Master Inspection Characteristic). This short text comes directly from the MIC master (QPMK-KURZTEXT).

There is no separate long text field in QAMV. Long texts for inspection characteristics are not stored as a simple field in a transparent table. Instead, SAP uses the SAPscript long text mechanism (clustered in STXH/STXL tables). The long text is linked to the MIC or inspection characteristic via text object and text ID.

As rightly said already, you can use standard function module READ_TEXT to read the long text QMSP_GET_LONGTEXT or QMSP_GET_TEXT â†’ Quality Management-specific function modules (depending on release). You pass the text object (e.g., QMST for MICs), text ID, and key (characteristic number) to retrieve the long description.

Select the cluster table for your localization (for Spain PCL2 - RE), switch it on and add the tables to decluster:

Setting Up Authorization for Payroll Control Center

entry.title: Re: Token Refreshes on Outbound OAuth 2.0 Client Settings...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you for your question.

When you ensure that your communication system is set up with OAuth 2.0 settings that include the token endpoint, client ID, and client secret, the system should automatically request a new token when the current one expires. For more information, see the following information:

Create Communication Arrangement Manually

I hope this answers your question. If not, please let us know.

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: SAP TM: Location still uses old address after Business Partner address change
entry.content:
Hi experts,

I am using Basic Transportation Management (TM) in an SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system.

Problem description

The Business Partner data of a ship-to party (goods recipient) was changed: a new address was maintained in the Business Partner master data. However, the TM location assigned to this ship-to party still contains the old address.

This leads to the following inconsistency:

In the outbound delivery, the correct (new) address is shown
In the Freight Unit, the old address is used, because the Freight Unit refers to the TM location
The address data of the TM location cannot be changed manually

I would have expected that either the TM location is updated automatically after a BP address change, or the location can be deleted and recreated with the new address

What I have tried so far

The TM location can only be marked for deletion. But actual deletion is not possible. I tried the following reports without success:

/SAPAPO/DELETE_LOCATIONS
/SAPAPO/DLOC_DEL_JOB

I also checked the following SAP Notes, but they did not solve the issue: 3486172 and 572579

Questions

Is it possible to fully delete a TM location that is assigned to a Business Partner (ship-to party)?

Is there a standard way to update or reprocess address changes from Business Partner master data into existing TM locations?

If deletion is not possible:

What is the recommended standard approach to handle address changes for ship-to locations in SAP TM?

Is there a way to force TM to create a new location with the updated address?

Any guidance, standard behavior explanation, or best practice would be highly appreciated.

entry.title: SAP Composable Storefront: Correct steps to move from B2C to B2B setup
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I need some guidance on the correct approach to move from a B2C Composable Storefront to a B2B Composable Storefront in SAP Commerce.

Current situation:

  • I initially installed and developed a B2C Composable Storefront.

  • Later, I realized that B2C is no longer needed and the project must be B2B only.

  • I have already created a new B2B Composable Storefront installation in a separate folder.

  • I want to keep all the custom work done in the B2C storefront (custom components, services, CMS components, styles, configurations) and reuse it in the B2B storefront.

Questions:

  1. What are the recommended and SAP-supported steps to move from a B2C Composable Storefront to B2B?

  2. Is there any official documentation or best practice that explains this transition?

Goal:
End up with a single B2B Composable Storefront, fully functional, containing all the customizations originally developed for B2C, and aligned with SAP best practices to avoid future upgrade issues.

 

Thank you in advance.

Stefania

entry.title: Expired Product Management in Medical Device Industry using S/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction:  

This blog outlines th leading medical device industry business process steps to return expired products from the field and to replenish for the depleted stocks due to return of expired products.

In the field instruments and implants can expire for various reasons, companies regularly monitor products on the field for expiration and pull them of the shelves and replenish them with new stocks. This process prevents expired products from reaching the customers.

Pre-requisite:

  • The goods due expiration in the field consigned to customers or branch
  • The materials are tracked using reports generated out of S4
  • Hospitals and branches must be set up as customers
  • Instruments and Consumables set up separate materials.

Process Flow:

 

Process Flow: Replenishment

Process Flow: Return Expired

 Setup Steps:

Configure new consignment document type: -

Step 1: Define Consignment fill up and pick up document types

SPRO â€“ Sales and Distribution â€“ Sales document- Sales document header â€“ Define sales document type.

Consignment Pick up â€“ To pick up inventory from branch A back to the warehouse and virtual storage location

Consignment Fill up. â€“ To deliver inventory to sales rep B

Step 2: Define item categories.

SPRO â€“ Sales and Distribution â€“ Sales document- Sales document item â€“ Define item categories

Consignment pick-up item category

Consignment Fill-up Item category.

Step 3: Schedule lines

SPRO â€“ Sales and Distribution â€“ Sales document- Schedule lines â€“ Define schedule lines.

Consignment Pickup Schedule line.


Consignment Fill up the schedule line

Step 4: Assign document type to the sales area.

SPRO â€“ Sales and Distribution â€“ Sales document- Sales document header â€“ Assign Sales Area to Sales Document Types

Step 5: Assign Item Categories

SPRO â€“ Sales and Distribution â€“ Sales document- Sales document item - Assign Item Categories

Step 6: Assign Schedule Line Categories

SPRO â€“ Sales and Distribution â€“ Sales document- Schedule lines - Assign Schedule Line Categories

Process steps: -

Step 1: - Create pick up order (KA) To pick up inventory from branch A


Step 2: Create Inbound delivery and receive goods in the warehouse of origin and virtual storage location.

Step 3. Create a Consignment fill up (KB) order transfer/deliver goods to branch B

Step 4: Create an outbound delivery with reference to the KB Order. Pick, pack, and Issue from the virtual storage location to rep B

Step 5: Asset updated with the new functional location


Conclusion:

  • After going through the above blog, the user should have learned how to pull back expired products from the field and replenish them with new stock in S4 HANA
  • Please provide your feedback/comments. You can ask Question / Answer for the open Questions in the SAP Community here

Reference:

 SAP Help Portal

Authors: Mohan Kaliyamoorthy and Immanuel Godwin Johnson

entry.title: Re: Best Practice and Rapid Deployment Solution for Emplo...
entry.content:
Hi SE9282,

For Best Practice  references related to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) and Employee Central Payroll (ECP) - including standard functionalities, implementation guidance, and deployment assets - below are the latest and most relevant official resources you can use for RFP preparation and project deliverables.

entry.title: Re: Customizing SAP EWM Warehouse Monitor Node
entry.content:
Hello @GK817 ,

First of all sorry the late answer. 

According to me, the availability of the node (out of the box solution) to create customized monitor is enough basis to state that this is a SAP recommended solution.

You can either copy the SAP standard monitor or create a custom one straight from scratch. In both cases; you copy as is and not change anything (I cannot imagine why you would) or change anything, it would still be a SAP standard copy; Same like you copy the customizing of SAP out the box delivered standard Warehouse 0001.

Based on my recent project experience, I can confirm that the updates do not flow to the custom monitor. You need to add the extra Object Class and Methods which are delivered by SAP as a part of upgrade to your custom monitor .

entry.title: Re: The Only Script you would ever need for Message Logging and Custom Headers in SAP CI
entry.content:
Hello @vinaymittal,Why are you providing Groovy scripts that do not follow best practices?


Reading the message body as a String causes unnecessary high memory consumption. As a best practice, you should always guide your audience to use InputStream instead, especially in SAP CPI, where payload sizes can be large and memory management is critical.


Please make corrections whenever possible and improve the examples to reflect recommended best practices.

entry.title: Re: Proactive Warranty Monitoring in SAP PM: A Custom ABAP Solution
entry.content:
Hi Jelena, sorry about that. I gladly provide you with the entire code. 

REPORT y_pm_gewaehrl_ende_liste.

TABLES: iflot, equi.

TYPES: BEGIN OF zgewaehr_line,
         objektart TYPE char10,
         nummer    TYPE char30,
         beginn    TYPE sy-datum,
         ende      TYPE sy-datum,
         resttage  TYPE i,
         status    TYPE char40,
       END OF zgewaehr_line.

DATA: lv_today  TYPE sy-datum,
      lv_days   TYPE i,
      lv_start  TYPE sy-datum,
      lv_end    TYPE sy-datum,
      lt_output TYPE TABLE OF zgewaehr_line,
      ls_output TYPE zgewaehr_line,
      lv_mail_needed TYPE abap_bool.

lv_today = sy-datum.

" Selektionsbildschirm
SELECT-OPTIONS: s_tplnr FOR iflot-tplnr,
                s_equnr FOR equi-equnr.
PARAMETERS: p_rest  TYPE i DEFAULT 90 OBLIGATORY, " Standard 90 Tage
            p_email TYPE ad_smtpadr LOWER CASE,
            p_send  AS CHECKBOX DEFAULT ' '.

START-OF-SELECTION.

  " --- Technische PlÃ¤tze ---
  IF s_tplnr[] IS NOT INITIAL.
    SELECT tplnr, objnr
      FROM iflot
      INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_tpl)
      WHERE tplnr IN @s_tplnr.

    LOOP AT lt_tpl INTO DATA(ls_tpl).
      CLEAR: lv_start, lv_end, ls_output.

      SELECT SINGLE gwldt, gwlen
        FROM bgmkobj
        INTO (@lv_start, @LV_end)
        WHERE j_objnr = @LS_tpl-objnr.

      IF lv_start IS INITIAL OR lv_end IS INITIAL.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      ls_output-objektart = 'TPL'.
      ls_output-nummer    = ls_tpl-tplnr.
      ls_output-beginn    = lv_start.
      ls_output-ende      = lv_end.

      lv_days = lv_end - lv_today.
      ls_output-resttage = lv_days.

      IF lv_today >= lv_start AND lv_today <= lv_end.
        ls_output-status = 'GewÃ¤hrleistung vorhanden'.
      ELSEIF lv_today > lv_end.
        ls_output-status = 'GewÃ¤hrleistung abgelaufen'.
      ELSE.
        ls_output-status = 'GewÃ¤hrleistung noch nicht gÃ¼ltig'.
      ENDIF.

      " Nur innerhalb Restlaufzeit und nicht abgelaufen
      IF lv_days >= 0 AND lv_days <= p_rest.
        APPEND ls_output TO lt_output.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.

  " --- Equipment ---
  IF s_equnr[] IS NOT INITIAL.
    SELECT equnr, objnr
      FROM equi
      INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_equi)
      WHERE equnr IN @s_equnr.

    LOOP AT lt_equi INTO DATA(ls_equi).
      CLEAR: lv_start, lv_end, ls_output.

      SELECT SINGLE gwldt, gwlen
        FROM bgmkobj
        INTO (@lv_start, @LV_end)
        WHERE j_objnr = @LS_equi-objnr.

      IF lv_start IS INITIAL OR lv_end IS INITIAL.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      ls_output-objektart = 'EQ'.
      ls_output-nummer    = ls_equi-equnr.
      ls_output-beginn    = lv_start.
      ls_output-ende      = lv_end.

      lv_days = lv_end - lv_today.
      ls_output-resttage = lv_days.

      IF lv_today >= lv_start AND lv_today <= lv_end.
        ls_output-status = 'GewÃ¤hrleistung vorhanden'.
      ELSEIF lv_today > lv_end.
        ls_output-status = 'GewÃ¤hrleistung abgelaufen'.
      ELSE.
        ls_output-status = 'GewÃ¤hrleistung noch nicht gÃ¼ltig'.
      ENDIF.

      " Nur innerhalb Restlaufzeit und nicht abgelaufen
      IF lv_days >= 0 AND lv_days <= p_rest.
        APPEND ls_output TO lt_output.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.

  " --- LIST-Ausgabe ---
  WRITE: / 'Objektart', 12 'Nummer', 32 'Beginn', 52 'Ende', 72 'Resttage', 82 'Status'.
  ULINE.

  LOOP AT lt_output INTO ls_output.
    IF ls_output-status = 'GewÃ¤hrleistung vorhanden'.
      FORMAT COLOR COL_POSITIVE INTENSIFIED ON. " GrÃ¼n
    ELSEIF ls_output-resttage <= p_rest OR lv_today > ls_output-ende.
      FORMAT COLOR COL_NEGATIVE INTENSIFIED ON. " Rot
    ELSE.
      FORMAT COLOR COL_NORMAL INTENSIFIED OFF.
    ENDIF.

    WRITE: / ls_output-objektart UNDER 'Objektart',
             ls_output-nummer    UNDER 'Nummer',
             ls_output-beginn    UNDER 'Beginn',
             ls_output-ende      UNDER 'Ende',
             ls_output-resttage  UNDER 'Resttage',
             ls_output-status    UNDER 'Status'.

    FORMAT COLOR OFF.
  ENDLOOP.

  " --- PrÃ¼fen, ob Mail nÃ¶tig ---
  lv_mail_needed = abap_false.
  LOOP AT lt_output INTO ls_output.
    IF ls_output-resttage < 90.
      lv_mail_needed = abap_true.
      EXIT.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.

  " --- Mailversand ---
  IF p_send = 'X' AND p_email IS NOT INITIAL AND lv_mail_needed = abap_true.
    PERFORM send_email USING p_email lt_output.
  ENDIF.

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Mailversand
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM send_email USING pv_email TYPE ad_smtpadr pt_data TYPE STANDARD TABLE.
  DATA: lv_body      TYPE string,
        lv_line      TYPE string,
        lt_mail_body TYPE soli_tab,
        ls_mail_line TYPE soli.

  lv_body = 'GewÃ¤hrleistungen die in den nÃ¤chsten 90 Tagen enden.:' && cl_abap_char_utilities=>cr_lf.

  LOOP AT pt_data INTO ls_output.
    lv_line = |{ ls_output-objektart } { ls_output-nummer } Beginn: { ls_output-beginn DATE = USER } Ende: { ls_output-ende DATE = USER } Resttage: { ls_output-resttage } Status: { ls_output-status }|.
    CONCATENATE lv_body lv_line cl_abap_char_utilities=>cr_lf INTO lv_body.
  ENDLOOP.

  SPLIT lv_body AT cl_abap_char_utilities=>cr_lf INTO TABLE DATA(lt_lines).
  LOOP AT lt_lines INTO DATA(lv_text).
    ls_mail_line-line = lv_text.
    APPEND ls_mail_line TO lt_mail_body.
  ENDLOOP.

  TRY.
      DATA(lo_send_request) = cl_bcs=>create_persistent( ).
      DATA(lo_document)     = cl_document_bcs=>create_document(
                                i_type    = 'RAW'
                                i_text    = lt_mail_body
                                i_subject = 'SAP Systemnachricht: GewÃ¤hrleistungen laufen aus.' ).
      lo_send_request->set_document( lo_document ).
      lo_send_request->add_recipient( cl_cam_address_bcs=>create_internet_address( pv_email ) ).
      lo_send_request->set_send_immediately( 'X' ).
      DATA(lv_sent) = lo_send_request->send( ).
      IF lv_sent = abap_false.
        MESSAGE 'Mail konnte nicht gesendet werden' TYPE 'E'.
      ENDIF.
      COMMIT WORK.
    CATCH cx_document_bcs INTO DATA(lx_doc).
      MESSAGE lx_doc->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

entry.title: Re: Fixing Warranty Inheritance Issues in SAP PM: A Custom ABAP Report
entry.content:
complete code: 

REPORT y_pm_tp_inherit_warranty.

PARAMETERS: p_tplnr TYPE iflot-tplnr OBLIGATORY,
            p_test  AS CHECKBOX DEFAULT abap_true.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_child,
         tplnr TYPE iflot-tplnr,
         objnr TYPE iflot-objnr,
       END OF ty_child.

DATA: lv_objnr_parent      TYPE iflot-objnr,
      lt_child             TYPE TABLE OF ty_child,
      lv_pattern           TYPE string,
      lv_status            TYPE string,
      wa_bgmkobj_parent    TYPE bgmkobj,
      wa_bgmkobj_child     TYPE bgmkobj.

" Authorization check notice
AUTHORITY-CHECK OBJECT 'I_FL' ID 'TPLNR' FIELD p_tplnr ID 'ACTVT' FIELD '02'.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  WRITE: / 'Notice: Authorization check failed. Please verify permissions.'.
ENDIF.


" 1. Read parent functional location
SELECT SINGLE objnr
  FROM iflot
  INTO @LV_objnr_parent
  WHERE tplnr = @p_tplnr.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  MESSAGE 'Parent functional location not found' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.


" 2. Read warranty data for parent location
SELECT SINGLE *
  FROM bgmkobj
  INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF @wa_bgmkobj_parent
  WHERE j_objnr = @LV_objnr_parent.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
  MESSAGE 'No warranty data found for parent location' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.


" 3. Read child locations
lv_pattern = p_tplnr && '%'.

SELECT tplnr, objnr
  FROM iflot
  INTO TABLE @LT_child
  WHERE tplnr LIKE @LV_pattern
    AND tplnr <> @p_tplnr.

IF lt_child IS INITIAL.
  MESSAGE 'No subordinate functional locations found' TYPE 'I'.
ENDIF.

WRITE: / 'Parent location:', p_tplnr,
       / 'Test run:', p_test.


" 4. Process child locations using MODIFY
LOOP AT lt_child ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<child>).
  IF p_test = abap_true.
    lv_status = |SIMULATION: Location { <child>-tplnr } would be updated or newly created.|.
  ELSE.
    CLEAR wa_bgmkobj_child.
    wa_bgmkobj_child = wa_bgmkobj_parent.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-j_objnr = <child>-objnr;
    wa_bgmkobj_child-erdat   = sy-datum.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-erzei   = sy-uzeit.
    wa_bgmkobj_child-gaerb   = 'X'.

    " MODIFY decides whether INSERT or UPDATE
    MODIFY bgmkobj FROM @wa_bgmkobj_child.

    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      lv_status = |Location { <child>-tplnr } processed successfully.|.
    ELSE.
      lv_status = |Error processing location { <child>-tplnr }.|.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

  WRITE: / lv_status.
ENDLOOP.

IF p_test = abap_false.
  COMMIT WORK.
  WRITE: / 'Changes have been saved.'.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Test run completed. No changes saved.'.
ENDIF.

entry.content:
Hello @jenny_geipel ,

We are currently piloting AI-Assisted Goal Writing in SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, and we are seeing consistent behavior where the AI generates content for fields such as goal description / success criteria, but does not populate the Goal Name field.

Here are the details:

  • AI-Assisted Goal Writing is enabled in Provisioning and Admin Center

  • The feature works correctly for other goal fields

  • The Goal Name field remains blank after running AI

 

My questions:

  1. Is this behavior by design â€” meaning AI will skip the Goal Name field ?

  2. Is there any fallback logic planned (e.g., deriving the goal name from the generated description)?

  3. Is this documented as expected behavior, or should customers expect Goal Name to be generated by default in the future?

This seems to be a common point of confusion for admins, since the Goal Name is arguably one of the most important field during goal creation.

Any official confirmation or documentation pointers would be appreciated.

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: Automatically splitting items in a PI document when t...
entry.content:
Hello @Nihit 

Thank you for your question.

In public cloud, embedded EWM, the system restricts inventory document to a maximum of 999 item. See https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/c4d063c8a0874231bf75a5b4c83ddddc.html for more information.

That means when your annual physical inventory selection produces more than 999 HUs, then you must create the PI documents and use a method that helps you enforce splitting. See https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/e54b33636b9a4a96984d8d1e9b98f92a.html for further insights.

You can use the app Schedule the Creations of Physical Inventory Documents and set the Maximum number of items to any value below 999. This will help you create multiple PI documents automatically for the same selection. After that, you can execute Count Physical Inventory for each document you create.

You can achieve it through the delivered scheduling and mass processing settings; it is not a backend table correction in public cloud.

Here is a quick guide 

Step 1: Open Schedule the Creation of Physical Inventory Document, enter your warehouse and any relevant selection (procedure AS or AL, physical inventory area and activity area as your process may require), maintain maximum numbers of items and schedule the job run to immediately or your desired time.

Step 2: Then open Create Physical Inventory Document, then filter by the same warehouse and same selection criteria and confirm that you now have multiple PI documents, each not having more than 999 items.

Step 3: Open Count Physical Inventory, select one of the split PI documents and perform counting and posting as per your process.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
